/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I'm still working on giving this change a deeper review.
This looks reasonable.  We have a customer hitting this problem as well.

Unfortunately, the person who encountered this bug is no longer with us, so I woulds have to recreate the test they made (we have no records of them :( ).

Nevertheless, seeing this is a problem that has not only presented to our team (as Hemna accounts) and that the fix has ran smoothly for us (fixes the bug and no other bugs have stemmed from it), what are your reservations about including this fix ?

I still don't see how
    shaindex >= len(parent_backup_shalist)

would happen exactly.  This change seems like it might be patching over a bug that needs to be fixed elsewhere.  Or maybe some explanation of what is going on is missing?
I will meet with the team tht found the bug and get back to you with a more concrete explanation.

My questions would be: What's the intention of the original code comparing to parent shas? The fix implies that there might be more chunks now then there were in the parent backup. Is there a problem with reading "sparse" files and thus when a backup grows in comparison to previous backups?

We could by now find out how this happens in our environment (with the vmware driver): Reading the disk from VMware returns a streamOptimized version which compresses away all empty blocks. Therefore, the chunkeddriver doesn't walk the whole disk and thus the first backup doesn't include all chunks of the disk - just the used ones. Therefore, as soon as the user writes more data into the disk, the parent backup contains less chunks than the new increment.

The main problem here is, that the incremental backup is not optimal with this fix, as the parent could contain chunks [A, B] and the increment could contain the chunks [A, C, B] as one could write to different parts of the disk. The driver would then compare A to A, C to B, B to nothing and thus not recognize that it would really only have to save C as new chunk. Instead, it would save C and B again.

Therefore, I think the real solution would be to extrude/explode/unpack the source file into raw format so all blocks can be read.

Under what circumstance would this happen?

It's not clear to me why we need to add this check.

We encountered the IndexError discribed in the bug report <https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1962607> consistently while running tests for incremental backups.

Adding this changes handles the error and allows the tests to run smoothly.
Understood, but it's not clear why this is the correct way to fix this.  I'd like to know how this case can actually happen.

Our test for incremental backaups were ran with the following procedure:

1. An instance is created with a cinder volume of 25GB.

2. A full backup is created.

3. A file (1GB) is created in the instance. Command: dd if=/dev/zero of=/home/ubuntu/test_vol_day1.img bs=20M count=50

4. An incremental backup is created. Command: openstack volume backup create --incremental --force --name backup_full_01_inc_day01 vol_boot20. Here, the IndexError is raised. If we run the command again, it works.

5. steps 3 and4 are repeated twice, encountering no problems.

6. an Ubuntu ISO (2GB) is downloaded into the instance.

7. An incremental backup is created. Command: openstack volume backup create --incremental --force --name backup_full_01_inc_day04 vol_boot20. Same IndexError is encountered. Re-running the command does not work as before.

8. Incremental volumes are re-built in new instances validating the existance of the files created in each step.

designate/objects/rrdata_txt.py.message:
RFC 1464 discusses the case where quotes are valid in strings when they are esacped with '`' or '\', so this regex would block valid strings that have escaped single instances of a double quote.
It would be an odd instance, but allowed by the RFC.

Example, "string=\"Cat"

I think we should discard escaped quotes or maybe just check that the string also ends in a '"' if it starts with one.
Checked that the string also ends with a double quote if it starts with double quote.
We probably want to capture the other way too. A missing " at the beginning, but one at the end.

Previously, filters were applied after retrieving all ports. This patch turns filters into query parameters. This changes the behavior of the module.

We could also simply stick to the old functionality (self.conn.search_ports instead of self.conn.network.ports) without loosing anything. 

What do we gain here?

We decided to stick to cloud layer functions here to not break backward compatibility. The cloud layer is not going away and proxy layer does not support filters, only query params which implement a subset of filters only.

Ref.: https://meetings.opendev.org/irclogs/%23openstack-sdks/%23openstack-sdks.2022-04-27.log.html

If we decide to use query params instead of filters then we should probably consider to update the module argument specs. For example, we could drop the filters argument and add a new arg which resembles query args. Doing so would cause the user code to break which is what we want because then its easier for users to see that they have to update their code.

The most user friendly decision would be to stick to the cloud layer function as before because search_ports() do the same as the proxy layer network.ports() plus it implements filters.

My information may be somewhat outdated, is there an argreement to drop the openstack_ prefix?

We agreed to drop the 'openstack_*' prefix because (a) it was not consistently used across modules in the past, (b) its less to type without the prefix and (c) to signal to users that they have to adopt their code to the updated return values. A lot of modules have different return values with openstacksdk>=0.99.0 because openstacksdk consistently uses resource proxies now.

We didn't note it down somewhere, but yes, that's the plan for 2.0.0. I'm thinking it might be a bit more sensible to keep the openstack_* fields around but deprecated for 2.0.0 and remove them in a (maybe) distant 3.0.0

by the way the hyperv driver was the first to support secureboot using os:secure_boot

when we added secure boot support to the libvirt driver we chose to reuse the same flavor and image properties that hyperv already used so this isnt libvirt specific.

we intentionally used os:secure_boot so that end users did not need to care if it was hyperv libvirt or now ironic.

so you are not really alinging with the libvirt driver but rather the standared trait which we have codifed in our flavor validateion code.

all standard extra specs supported by intree drviers should have a validator in 
https://github.com/openstack/nova/tree/master/nova/api/validation/extra_specs

and all unnamespaced extra spec should be deprecated and aliased with a namespaced version.

does ironic have any other setting like this one that you are just passing striat though because techincally speceing every time you and an extra specs you are ment to have a specless blueprint and or a spec for the feature.

so ironic should not use the extra specs as an opaque bag of string that are directly passthough to ironic.

while adding extra specs is not considered a microversion bump its still a non versioned api change so they should still be reviewed via a spec or specless blueprint to try and fined extra specs that are portable across drivers.

If apparmor is off by default anyway, then what is the purpose of this "related-to" commit which seems to turn it off by default?

The LSM module apparmor can only be supported by built-into the kernel but not a loaded kernel module and there are no other LSM security plugins in LSM list in current Debian kernel, if it does not be turned off with kernel parameters like the related-to commit does, apparmor will be enabled by default. But WRCP's requirement is supporting it in kernel but not enable it by default, so the related commit will turn it off.
It really does make sense, I have updated. Thank you so much.

OK, so it sounds to me like this label should be "Depends-On" to ensure that the tools repo commit goes in first.  Otherwise if this commit goes in without the tools repo commit, apparmor will be enabled which could cause problems.

If the tools repo commit goes in first by itself, it is not a problem since linux kernel bootargs that are not recognized are simply silently ignored.
I would add a line here that says that the following tools repo commit ensures that apparmor is disabled by default.

cinder/tests/unit/test_volume_utils.py.message: IMO, this should be in a separate test.  That way you don't have to worry about resetting the image properties, but also you need to check the case where the virtual_size is None (and for really old, images, it might not even be present).

cinder/volume/volume_utils.py.message:
For volume-create, this isn't called until cinder.volume.flows.api.create_volume ... isn't that too late for the REST API to reject the request?

It's also called by cinder.volume.api.reimage, but that's done before the rpcapi call is made, so I think that one is OK.

OK, looked more closely, looks like ImageUnacceptable will be raised when flow_engine.run() is called (just like InvalidAvailabilityZone is), so it will happen synchronously with the call to volume_api.create_volume() the REST API, which is exactly what we want.

Initially I was thinking of doing it as early as when checking the image_id[1] but 
we don't fetch the image_metadata until[2] (which is in the file you mentioned) and we check the metadata properties right after that.
The reason for not doing it earlier is it will add an additional API call to glance to fetch the metadata which is an overhead in the most common operation i.e. creating a volume and we won't fail every time but we will fetch metadata (additionally) every time. My thinking is, until we are failing in the API and synchronously we should be good and not wasting end users time waiting for the operation to fail.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/commit/a2deecef891a16703e5410eb7805442961307090/cinder/volume/api.py#L239-L240
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/commit/a2deecef891a16703e5410eb7805442961307090/cinder/volume/flows/api/create_volume.py#L251
Yes, I've tested in my environment that it fails synchronously (in the API layer).

releasenotes/notes/added-virtual-size-ch.message:
virtual_size isn't populated on legacy images (and possibly some new images in weird formats), so I think we need to make clear here that we're relying on an image property to do this check.  Maybe something like:

When creating a volume from an image, a check has been added to compare the requested volume size to the image's ``virtual_size`` property and fail the request if the volume will be too small to contain the image.  If the image record does not contain this property, the request is accepted but the volume will go to ``error`` status if the image does not fit (which is the current behavior).
Should we start documenting these behaviors somewhere?

I don't see any _escape_snapshot() function defined (or invoked). Maybe this is something borrowed from the LVM driver, but really doesn't apply to the DataCore driver?

I think you are either missing the escape code and need to add it, or the unescape code needs to be removed.

Yes, I borrowed it from LVM driver because while running "tempest.api.volume.admin.test_snapshot_manage.SnapshotManageAdminTest.test_unmanage_manage_snapshot" test I was getting snapshot name as "_snapshot-28d1a530-ac81-4e85-b1e4-9ae6733e6738" and extract_id_from_snapshot_name was not working when the name is prefixed with "_".

I'm still confused by this statement. The LVM driver controls its snapshot name, and has its own reason for needing to escape/unescape the name. I may be wrong, but this sounds like you encountered a tempest failure, and got the problem to "go away" by adding this unescape() code.  I don't believe other drivers need to do this, and so I fear there may be a root cause that should be investigated.

I found the root cause. In the "tempest.conf" there is a variable `manage_snapshot_ref` which is set to source-name,_snapshot-%s by default. That's the reason I was getting _snapshot in the name.(https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/sampleconf.html). So setting it to `manage_snapshot_ref = source-name,%s` solved my issue.

Thank you.

src/reactive/designate_handlers.py.message: Ideally this pattern would be in charms.openstack but I'm not going to block on it. Can change the doc string to be the same as https://github.com/openstack/charm-manila/blob/b75e6ed3ce6b2c061105ac8226a778e1ec3685d4/src/reactive/manila_handlers.py#L178 otherwise the method seems very odd.

Unfortunately the method in charms.openstack which runs the db sync does not raise a flag to indicate that the db sync is done, however we do not want to try and start the services until that happens.
Also, I don't think there is any reason to limit this to the `designate-mdns` service, I think the same logic should apply to all designate services. `disable_services` and `enable_services` can be used to manage this.

I think you can achieve this with something like:

```
    with charm.provide_charm_instance() as instance:
        if instance.db_sync_done():
            instance.enable_services()
        else:
            hookenv.log(
                "Services not enabled, waiting for db sync",
                 level=hookenv.WARNING)
```

As mentioned above lets not make the `designate-mdns` service a special case unless we have to. Since you already have a instance of the charm class you can change this to:

```
    instance.disable_services()
```

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Hi, hirotaka, Do you know why we need  this route ?

Hi Wu! Thanks for asking my comment. 

I think we should not remove this replace because the routing entry is used to reach hosts on private network via public bridge network(br-ex).

`ip route replace` will create a routing entry when no routes to be replaced exist. Here is a simple test in my environment to reach mariadb port from devstack host.

1. Checks the current routing table and ip and port reachability.
`10.0.0.0` is the default private network address.
```
$ netstat -rn|grep 10.0.0.0
10.0.0.0        172.24.4.107    255.255.252.0   UG        0 0          0 br-ex
$ nc -zv 10.0.0.37 3306
Connection to 10.0.0.37 3306 port [tcp/mysql] succeeded!
```

2. Removes the routing entry.
```
$ sudo ip route delete 10.0.0.0/22 via 172.24.4.107
```

3. Checks the current routing table and ip and port reachability.
```
$ netstat -rn|grep 10.0.0.0
$ nc -zv 10.0.0.37 3306
nc: connect to 10.0.0.37 port 3306 (tcp) failed: No route to host
```

4. Adds the routing entry using `replace` command
```
$ sudo ip route replace 10.0.0.0/22 via 172.24.4.107
```

5. Checks the current routing table and ip and port reachability.
```
$ netstat -rn|grep 10.0.0.0
10.0.0.0        172.24.4.107    255.255.252.0   UG        0 0          0 br-ex
$ nc -zv 10.0.0.37 3306
Connection to 10.0.0.37 3306 port [tcp/mysql] succeeded!
```

Here are some stack.sh logs in my environment.
```
$ grep -E "ROUTER_GW_IP|IPV4_ADDRS_SAFE_TO_USE|10.0.0.0" logs/stack.sh.log
2022-07-15 03:13:07.247 | ++ lib/neutron_plugins/services/l3:create_neutron_initial_network:158 :   oscwrap --os-cloud devstack-admin --os-region RegionOne subnet pool create shared-default-subnetpool-v4 --default-prefix-length 26 --pool-prefix 10.0.0.0/22 --share --default -f value -c id
2022-07-15 03:13:29.643 | + lib/neutron_plugins/services/l3:_neutron_configure_router_v4:350 :   ROUTER_GW_IP='   172.24.4.107  '
2022-07-15 03:13:29.645 | + lib/neutron_plugins/services/l3:_neutron_configure_router_v4:351 :   die_if_not_set 351 ROUTER_GW_IP 'Failure retrieving ROUTER_GW_IP'
2022-07-15 03:14:30.539 |   IPV4_ADDRS_SAFE_TO_USE: 10.0.0.0/22
2022-07-15 03:14:30.539 |   FIXED_RANGE: 10.0.0.0/22
2022-07-15 03:14:30.539 |   SUBNETPOOL_PREFIX_V4: 10.0.0.0/22
2022-07-15 03:14:30.539 |   ROUTER_GW_IP:    172.24.4.107  
2022-07-15 03:14:40.101 | ++ /opt/stack/trove/devstack/plugin.sh:config_trove_network:541 :   sudo ip route replace 10.0.0.0/22 via 172.24.4.107
2022-07-15 03:14:48.289 | | 45216809-50b4-484e-9ad9-bccdb3147f0d | private-subnet    | 82645d6d-69fa-44e9-a0db-8374c0e2696a | 10.0.0.0/26      |
2022-07-15 03:14:49.932 | 10.0.0.0/22 via 172.24.4.107 dev br-ex
```

and here are neutron settings of devstack/local.conf in my environment.
```
# Use openvswitch as the ml2 plugin driver
Q_AGENT=openvswitch
Q_ML2_PLUGIN_MECHANISM_DRIVERS=openvswitch
Q_PLUGIN=ml2
Q_ML2_TENANT_NETWORK_TYPE=vxlan
Q_DVR_MODE=legacy

# Neutron
enable_service q-svc
enable_service q-agt
enable_service q-dhcp
enable_service q-l3
enable_service q-meta
```

Thanks in advance,

distributedcloud/dccommon/consts.py.message: I think this name will be different on CentOS and Debian. On CentOS it will remains as "ca-cert.pem (even though I think ca-cert.crt will work on CentOS as well, I think it should be kept as it is to minimize impact on CentOS), on Debian it will be "ca-cert.crt" (required by update-ca-certificates).
Hi Li, if you confirm update-ca-certificates will add ca-cert.pem in the bundle file, we don't nee to distinguish them. My impression is update-ca-certificates only take .crt file.

Yes, it only takes .crt file. I assume the ca-cert.crt will be put under /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors and update-ca-certificates will point to this directory, then there's corrresponding ca-cert.pem file will be generated under /etc/ssl/certs, meanwhile it will be added to the certificates bundle. But either way works, so I'll change to what you suggested. I think what you suggested is more reliable and no assumption :)
After running update-ca-certificates, the ca-cert.pem will be generated under /etc/ssl/certs, but anyway, I'll change it to ca-cert.crt and then the directory will be same on both operating system.

controllerconfig/controllerconfig/script.message: I think this on Debian (c_rehash extract) is a silent failure. It scan directory "extract" and will find no cert but still return 0 ($? = 0)

You can set for CentOS:
UPDATE_CA_CMD = upate-ca-trust extract

And for Debian just:
UPDATE_CA_CMD = c_rehash

c_rehash by default will hash certs in:
[root@controller-0 ldap_certs(keystone_admin)]# c_rehash
Doing /usr/lib/ssl/certs

which is a symbolic link to:
[root@controller-0 ldap_certs(keystone_admin)]# ls  -l  /usr/lib/ssl/certs
lrwxrwxrwx 3 root root 14 Jun 28 14:06 /usr/lib/ssl/certs -> /etc/ssl/certs

/COMMIT_MSG.message: That's a valid failure case? If the operator has enabled [libvirt]volume_use_multipath and multipathd isn't running then get_connector_properties should fail IMHO.

If it stands as a valid case then we shouldn't be passing any parameter named enforce multipath to os_brick and remove this if statement[1] to fail always

[1] https://github.com/openstack/os-brick/blob/master/os_brick/initiator/linuxscsi.py#L219-L220
I don't think we want to allow this, in this case shouldn't the operator just disable [libvirt]volume_use_multipath if multipathd isn't running on their computes?

enforce mutlipath is used to provide choice if the operator wants to be strict about using multipath or not.
If enforce_multipath isn't set then they can freely set volume_use_multipath without worrying about failing operation (not bothering about if it uses multipath or not)
This new parameter doesn't change any current behavior, just provides some flexibility with multipathing.

-1: AFAIK that is false.  It can work with WWID, device path, or device ID, as explained by the man page.

SYNOPSYS
        multipath [-v level] [-l|-ll] [device]


ARGUMENTS
       The device argument restricts multipath's operation to devices matching the given expres‐
       sion.  The  argument  may refer either to a multipath map or to its components ("paths").
       The expression may be in one of the following formats:

       device node   file name of a device node, e.g. /dev/dm-10 or /dev/sda. If the node refers
                     to  an existing device mapper device representing a multipath map, this se‐
                     lects the map or its paths, depending on the operation mode. Otherwise,  it
                     selects a path device.

       device ID     kernel  device  number  specified  by major:minor numbers, e.g. 65:16. This
                     format can only be used for path devices.

       WWID          a World Wide Identifier matching a multipath map  or  its  paths.  To  list
                     WWIDs  of devices present in the system, use e.g. the command "multipath -d
                     -v3 2>/dev/null".

If that is the case then we are limited for now on the supported sssd core functionality.

The sssd-idp package I can found on the link:

Package sssd-idp
    bookworm (testing) (utils): System Security Services Daemon -- Kerberos plugins for external id providers
    2.7.3-1: amd64 arm64 armel armhf i386 mips64el mipsel ppc64el s390x

They are either testing or unstable, neither one is for bullseyes. And I don't think we want to support Kerberos as a external identity provider for the release.

I can add sssd-tools. But sssd-dbus is not in the dependency chain. What is it for?
sssd-idp is not in dependency chain either, and can't be found in Debian package official site (https://packages.debian.org/bullseye/sssd)

sssd-dbus and sssd-idp packages support SSSD core functionality. They are not dependencies.
sssd-dbus supports the d-bus interface and sssd-idp supports authentication against external identity providers. Debian packages for these features can be found at https://packages.debian.org/. They get installed automatically when installing sssd, at least for centos.
Will need to follow up on sssd-idp package and other core sssd packages as they become available on bullseye release.

As for sssd-dbus, I'm not sure you've ever installed sssd on Debian (we only need to support sssd on Debian), I didn't see sssd-dbus is installed automatically (because sssd doesn't depends on sssd-dbus package on Debian).

But if you see this package is nesessary, I'll try to include it.

re "yes and no",  yes was yes this would be out of scope if the neutron feature was integrated with nova and respresented in the metadata. currently, it is not
integrated with nova so if you set a default domain name on a network or port that info is only propagated to designate or used internally by neutron it is not consumed by nova or exposed in the instance metadata API.

cloud-init and other host agents don't consume per port DNS info today with regards to determining the content of /etc/hostname. if we were to start including that info per port all of the tools would have to be updated to consume it. perhaps that is the right approach but the dns_doamin is not a new extention on the port or network but they have not been request for this info before.

i kind of fundemantally disagree with the idea that hostname goes with the instnace and the domain is an an atribute of the newtork. at least to the extent that its inapproate to have a primary domain for an instance. the fact that we have hostname in the api was jsut for convinence and historical convenice due to how nova-network worked and some of the default behaivor of libvirt ectra. we could have entirly decoupled the isntance name form the hostname and alwasy declared that out of scope but since we did not we have this weired relationship where hostnames are instance specific FQDNs are not supported at all and doamins are network scoped?

that feels wrong to me and make me quetion if we should perhaps revert our prvious desion to sanitaise hostname.


by default neutron networks do not have domains, and its not support by all ml2 drivers as far as im aware. Where the nutron backend supprot per port or per network dns_domsins its a default domain to use when creating ports on that network that dont otherwise have a domain specified.

to me it seams rater restrictive to say that the only way to assocation a domain with a port is via neutron given its an optional part of there api. there would be no portable way to achive this across all clouds.

with that said i was orginally in the camp that this shoudl be done by neutron too.

that is where the "no" came in, if we agreed this was in scope of nova to do i think a top level instance domain is more appropriate then say addint the option to secicy a dns_domain per port when attaching a prot ro creating a vm in nova's api.

i.e. i would not supprot treating this like device role tagging where we store that info per port in our db or just proxy it to neutron.

i can see supporting it if its a per instance atibute.

failing that my prefernce would to be revisit the orginal desice to set hostname from a sanadtised verion fo displayname.

i.e. just allow FQDNs and fix nova interaction with neutron so that we can split the hoatname and domain name correctly.
ya im going to hold of  on commenting on this more i think until we do the revert or create a followup patch

yes and no. this feature has no depency on neutron or designate to achive its primary usecase of ensureing the metadtaa generated by nova contains an fqdn generate by combining the hostanem and domin name.

we have an optional dependency on the neutron per port dns name extention if and only if we want to propagate the domain name infor to neutron and transitivly to designate so that the vm is automatically resolvebale in dns.

this spec does not depend on the neutron extention however.
it would be feature complete without updating the neutron prot as long as the metadata is generated properly so that cloud-init or other guest level agents can retrieve the cannonical guest name.

> i kind of fundemantally disagree with the idea that hostname goes with the instnace and the domain is an an atribute of the newtork. at least to the extent that its inapproate to have a primary domain for an instance. the fact that we have hostname in the api was jsut for convinence and historical convenice due to how nova-network worked and some of the default behaivor of libvirt ectra. we could have entirly decoupled the isntance name form the hostname and alwasy declared that out of scope but since we did not we have this weired relationship where hostnames are instance specific FQDNs are not supported at all and doamins are network scoped?

In almost all modern scenarios that I know of, the client has some notion of its own name (either from config or told to it) and the network tells it what the FQDN is. The client says "I'm bob" and the network says "Okay, here you are bob.example.com". If that client goes to another network, the same thing happens, but for the other domain. In cases where clients tell the network that they already know their FQDN, either DDNS breaks or something along the line chops off the hostname, almost exclusively honoring only that part of what the client said.

> that feels wrong to me and make me quetion if we should perhaps revert our prvious desion to sanitaise hostname.

What does the decision to sanitize the hostname have to do with the rest of the FQDN? Or are you saying we should have answered the sanitization question with dropping it entirely?

> by default neutron networks do not have domains, and its not support by all ml2 drivers as far as im aware. Where the nutron backend supprot per port or per network dns_domsins its a default domain to use when creating ports on that network that dont otherwise have a domain specified.
> 
> to me it seams rater restrictive to say that the only way to assocation a domain with a port is via neutron given its an optional part of there api. there would be no portable way to achive this across all clouds.

I guess, but I would also say that if a cloud is using a network driver without this support, then they just don't support managing this for users. 

> with that said i was orginally in the camp that this shoudl be done by neutron too.
> 
> that is where the "no" came in, if we agreed this was in scope of nova to do i think a top level instance domain is more appropriate then say addint the option to secicy a dns_domain per port when attaching a prot ro creating a vm in nova's api.
> 
> i.e. i would not supprot treating this like device role tagging where we store that info per port in our db or just proxy it to neutron.
> 
> i can see supporting it if its a per instance atibute.
> 
> failing that my prefernce would to be revisit the orginal desice to set hostname from a sanadtised verion fo displayname.
> 
> i.e. just allow FQDNs and fix nova interaction with neutron so that we can split the hoatname and domain name correctly.

I dunno, I guess my point is that with displayname, it's truly the user's choice. Generating a hostname from that, if we know what works for the local network, makes sense to me either for nova or neutron to do with operator input. Letting people specify a rather critical network parameter with no input from the managed infrastructure that controls that just seems like a waste of time and invitation for confusion from users who are expecting this stuff to actually talk to each other. IMHO, well-behaved infrastructure would ensure that the hostname is set to *something* that is lookup-able in DNS and points back to us. Two instances with the same network config should have the same behavior. If the user wants to override it for vanity or other reasons, then either doing that through the network infrastructure (if possible) or through custom config seems like the right path to me.

Adding another field to nova that is just a passthrough to the instance but that is totally un-correllated to the rest of the infrastructure just seems pointless to me for an IaaS setup. That's the benefit openstack should be providing over just bare VMs on libvirt, and IIRC, is something that k8s makes a more critical part of how stuff works there. For the better.

i hate the resovled comment feature i acidentilly clicked it and lost what i had typed.

im going to wait tiil we either create a follow up or revert and repoen.

clip notes version of my respoce were yes we considered truncation in the past and if we had gone with that it would have allowed dns search domain from dhcp to be used to figure out the fqdn.

ovn only got support for the dns-domain-ports extensions in yoga
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/commit/8a890ed29c681847d930bdf5403926c2e1450f9d
it was one of the many feature gaps in its dns support.

Yes and no what? I know that this is currently proposed as just a hack in nova to let people plumb a domain name through to metadata that cloud-init can handle. What I'm saying is I think it's really not appropriate for us to be hacking around it in general.

I understand the concern of not knowing which domain from multiple ports should be the canonical one, but I'd much prefer to solve that than to just make more stuff that people have to pass in so that things work as they should. IIRC, our port list in our cache has to remain sorted for other reasons, so we could say "the first one is primary" or we could note the ID of the primary network or port in sysmeta to keep it consistent. Or we could add a flag to say "this is the network I want to be my primary" so that we can properly extract the domain name from it.

IMHO, the hostname goes with the instance, the domain name goes with the network, and the choice of primary affinity is the only thing we should really be exposing in a managed infrastructure arrangement like openstack.

In stable/train we use puppet instead of tripleo-firewall to manage firewall rules, so removing the clean up tasks means the task are not executed.

Looking at the current implementation, we don't have fully equivalent implementation in puppet-tripleo by default. However the puppet version of firewall resource provides the PurgeFirewallRules parameter, and when the parameter is set to true then puppet purges all firewall rules. I think removing the ansible tasks to purge rules are sane here, as the rules should NOT be purged unless PurgeFirewallRules is set, as long as we provide the parameter.

I'll check firewall rules applied in RDO jobs, to ensure we do not leave any strange rules by this removal.

Also, upgrade run (which runs the playbooks) use tripleo-admin[3].


[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/playbooks/cli-enable-ssh-admin.yaml#L182
[2] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/master/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_deploy.py#L1234
[3] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/master/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_upgrade.py#L156

The patch earlier in this series does exactly that. This is to ensure that we always run playbooks with 'tripleo-admin' (which we create and authorize if does not exist) irrespective of the overcloud-ssh-user provided, as we run upgrade with 'only' tripleo-admin'.

IMHO, maintaining irrelevant files and job dependencies in specific repos is better  than having a a superset in tripleo-ci which would be difficult to manage.

zuul.d/layout.yaml.message:
main concern about this is it could cause problems where a job needs to run (from one of those templates above) and it does not have a guard against irrelevant files or there is a mismatch between these irrelevant files and any defined for the given job.

So that job would depend on content provider but the provider is prevented from running because of the irrelevant file.

i.e. content provider is a special case because all other jobs depend on it.

we can go ahead with this but having in mind if we see problems we may need to revert if we cant "match" the irrelevant files in whichever job needs the content provider.

Oh -- there's probably also some bad/weird behavior we're fixing when shrinking away empty shards, too, huh....

Like, previously, you could short-circuit cleaving when shrinking, causing the shrunk shard to not get marked deleted for a bit (though I guess there's a fallback down around L1931).

swift/container/backend.py.message:
Feels weird to me that we're setting status_changed_at but not status, and delete_timestamp but not put_timestamp.... I guess put_timestamp got set in the initialize() call, though? And status will only ever be NULL (or is it blank?) or 'DELETED' -- and presumably we wouldn't call set_sharding_state() on a DB that's been flagged as deleted -- except, that seems to be *exactly* the case the commit message is worried about!

The more I think about it, it's kinda weird that these aren't *all* values we could pass to initialize()... but at least we're doing this all in a temp DB so we don't have to worry about something reading it while we're only part way through set_sharding_state()!

hmm, status isn't pulled out into get_info. So I see 2 possible options.

1. Just simplify this scope to just delete_timestamp
2. Maybe have a function that clones the container_info data so we can push it all into the fresh db.
3. Both, over 2 patches, so we can land the delete_timestamp one for next release.

put_timestamp is pulled across in the initialize. The delete_timestamp is really the big one where.
The status_changed_at I think is idividual for a replica, but because we're making the fresh db, in essence the same as the retiring db it should match.

  'reported_*' items are not sync'd because this is consistent with

  'hash' should not be sync'd because this DB has no object rows.

Thanks for the much better wording.

I'm going to need to remind myself of the significance of these before I can +2 this change. What do container-sync and reconciler do with a sharding DB that has no objects (except misplaced)?

Could we make this fix more targeted by breaking out just the delete_timestamp, status and status_changed_at items for now?

yeah, I could split these up if that makes sense. Yeah, moving the sync points to a now empty DB (though the rowid is maintained), probably does make much of a difference. I guess to get container_sync for example, working with sharded containers it'll keep the sync points in each shard.. same with the reconciler I guess.

The way I say it was if we're replacing the old retiring DB with a new one, it'll be nice if the new one had all the old metadata, for completeness sake. Might come in useful if we ever use this "retiring -> fresh" mechanism as a sort of vacuum. Or if we ever want to just shard off the start of a container.. which isn't in scope.. just thinking out loud.

nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/test_driver.message: since you are not using mock_caps to make any assertions in the test there is a differnt syntax you should use to intoduce the mock without introducing a name for the mock.

this is an example of the ohter syntax using new

so you should replace @mock.patch.object here and in the rest of the file
with 

@mock.patch.object(host.Host, "_check_machine_type", new=mock.Mock())
then you do not need to add mock_caps to the funciton signiture

you also do not need to set return_value=None since that is the default

instead of patching every single method, an alternative could have been to add the mock in the setUp() method for the whole test class, but given this test class is checking more than just the get_guest_config() method, I'm fine with using the decorators for each of the needed tests.
